question_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
question_list.text:
Our most serious faces we don
As the blamestorming session goes on.
Someone died. Who's to blame?
The one person we name
Is a janitor's helper named Juan.
question_list.question: Who do they blame in the blamestorming session after someone dies?
alternate_answers:
Based on the limericks, it seems the person they blame in the blamestorming session after someone dies is often a scapegoat or someone undeserving of the blame. 

For example, one limerick mentions:

"Someone died. Who's to blame?
The one person we name
Is a janitor's helper named Juan."

This suggests that in the blamestorming session, they unfairly blame an innocent person, like the janitor's helper Juan, rather than finding the true cause of the death.

question_list.author: MikeAq
question_list.text:
Mr. Thistle, what's this all about?
All our rules you dismiss — baldly flout.
I have read your epistle;
It made my hairs bristle.
I'm blowing the whistle — you're out!
question_list.question: Does Mr. Thistle follow our rules?
alternate_answers: Mr. Thistle does not follow the rules consistently. He often disregards them without explanation or justification.

Based on the limericks provided, the question appears to be about the limerick that mentions "Mr. Thistle". The relevant limerick is:

"Mr. Thistle, what's this all about? 
All our rules you dismiss — baldly flout.
I have read your epistle;
It made my hairs bristle.
I'm blowing the whistle — you're out!"

This limerick suggests that Mr. Thistle does not follow the rules, as the speaker is blowing the whistle on him for dismissing and flouting the rules.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
The sign Gentlemen hadn't meant him,
So the fool filled his tub to the brim.
"I'll swim home, all alone!"
He jumped in; with a groan
Watched the bathroom floor flood—man, that's dim!

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
Whatever's the matter with bubsy?
The trouble is, far too much grub, see.
All those chocolate gateaux
Means her girth grows and grows:
Short, but fatty and tubby (that's fubsy).

limerick_list.author: Andrew Burnet
limerick_list.text:
"I shall marry my mare—have her haltered!"
Cried the groom. The next day found him altered.
Though he managed a smile
As she clopped up the aisle,
When they got to the altar, he faltered.

limerick_list.author: Buonarotti
limerick_list.text:
On the altar the corporal's spread
'Neath the paten so fragments of bread
Won't be brushed to the floor,
And the Host we adore
Will be treated with reverence instead.

limerick_list.author: James Dobson
limerick_list.text:
CONVERSATION? We're starting to yell,
And our VOICES RANT ON, I can tell.
In the midst of this din,
I suppress a small grin
As both anagrams suit us quite well.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
"Where is Abel?" God asks. "I don't know.
Do I need to keep track of my bro?
Is his welfare," asks Cain,
"My concern?" (He was slain
By Cain's hand, and God knew it. Uh-oh!)

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
This exhilarant drug gets me high—
I'm no longer a shy kind of guy.
The first hours are best;
Later on, I'm depressed,
And I need more cocaine to get by.

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
You're my alibi — you alone know
That I never left home. Please don't go
Till you've made it quite clear
To the plods I was here —
It's important, and crucially so!

limerick_list.author: Mark Mironer
limerick_list.text:
The show Knight Rider featured a car
That's intelligent (more than the star).
Once inert, now alive
(And man, can it drive!).
Autogenesis took them quite far.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
My husband loves cream cheese with chives.
It's a diet on which the man thrives.
Though these herbs are a treat,
They're a food I can't eat.
I'm allergic; they give me the hives.

limerick_list.author: thaivic
limerick_list.text:
Tax avoidance? A move you'll not rue.
But evasion? Now that's something new.
You may serve five to ten
In a federal pen—
With a con who's just waiting for you.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
"Something foveate's  dented or pitted,
Like the skin of my cheek," I admitted.
"I used makeup to hide
That flawed skin from my bride,
And denied that my pride was half-witted."

limerick_list.author: Len Farano
limerick_list.text:
Sam sent twenty new puns just to kid
His old buddies, Fred, Billy and Sid.
He had hoped maybe half
Ought to make his chums laugh,
But by their count no pun in ten did.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
What's he making with care and aplomb?
It's a Valentine gift for his mom.
He'll cut out, for a start,
From red paper, a heart,
And then sign it quite simply: "LOVE TOM."

limerick_list.author: Carol June Hooker
limerick_list.text:
The oil paintings started to dry
As a vandal smelled fumes and stopped by.
Stinky turpentine taint
Meant he stripped off some paint
To deturpate the art.  Ugly guy!

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Jack's factory's now a closed shop.
Union membership starts at the top—
All except for the boss,
Who feels lost and is cross—
And goes down to the guy with the mop.

limerick_list.author: Jim Vincent
limerick_list.text:
"Fair & Balanced," Fox News is no ruse.
They report and want viewers to choose.
As their slogan suggests,
They have Right and Left guests.
Other networks are singing the blues.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
It's the same on both sides of the pond:
Say "I dare you!" and kids will respond.
Why it works, I don't know,
But I daresay they'll go
To the ends of the earth and beyond.

limerick_list.author: VERaLOE
limerick_list.text:
Some people look puzzled and shrug:
My electromechanical mug
Can pour milk in my tea
And then stir it for me —
As long as they don't pull the plug.

limerick_list.author: mrsrev
limerick_list.text:
That horse is a real thoroughbred.
See him chak now? He tosses his head
Since his bridle and bit
Really don't seem to fit
And they're making the stallion see red.

limerick_list.author: AndrewB
limerick_list.text:
On black silicon I shall expound:
On its surface, small structures are found.
They're too small for your eye,
Roughly ten microns high,
Each a needle-like tall, skinny mound.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
All her life my dear wife had a hope
She might bathe with autumnal (fall) soap.
Winter, summer and spring
I'd find soap I could bring;
But not fall soap — nope, false hope.  She'd mope.

limerick_list.author: mrsrev
limerick_list.text:
In Argentine culture of yore,
The Aguada tribes lived, and what's more,
They made copper and bronze
Things, like vases and swans,
And some pottery people adore.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
"Living daylights": a phrase that's mysterious.
Is its meaning amusing or serious?
Came the weekend, no doubt,
Boris beat them straight out
Of his foe. The result? Deleterious!

limerick_list.author: buttonbright
limerick_list.text:
It won't win our trust, necessarily,
To brush off unpleasantness airily.
That tone, though it's breezy,
May leave us uneasy,
For wise is the one who treads warily.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
With the cards stacked against me, I know
That good luck is not likely to show.
My prediction?  The day
When success comes my way
Will see Hell as a blanket of snow.

limerick_list.author: John Ramos
limerick_list.text:
Said the man to a bear of great girth,
"I describe the fine creatures of Earth.
It's my job: I'm a faunist,
A naturalist—honest!
So, please, let me watch you give birth."

limerick_list.author: Sussexdownsman
limerick_list.text:
To this orchestra's fame others yield
In the popular light music field.
Of them all they are tops,
Yes, the great Boston Pops.
For one hundred plus years they've appealed.

limerick_list.author: Janet McConnaughey
limerick_list.text:
Shot in IMAX 3-D: zooming chases,
Cruel villains in glamorous places,
And then, at the climax,
Huge Ariolimax
(Banana slugs) squirm at our faces.

limerick_list.author: Bluebelle
limerick_list.text:
Nick the Nicker is mending quite well
Since his brush with the Reaper. The smell
Of decay is receding.
Now, no longer bleeding,
Convalescent, he's back in his cell.

limerick_list.author: psheil
limerick_list.text:
If you're Cymric, it means you are Welsh,
And you're used to the weather that's melsh.
But the floods of last week
Washed out more than a leek—
Many homes, being sodden, now squelch.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
Though I think that I'm growing obsessed
With the tenderest part of your breast,
I've decided to try
Either wings or a thigh,
To determine which parts I like best.

limerick_list.author: Carol June Hooker
limerick_list.text:
In Saint Louis, a conicoid waffle,
Folded cone-like by Hamwi, felt awful:
"Other waffles conoidal
Salve ailments lymphoidal
With ice cream, while I hold falafel!"

limerick_list.author: StephenGold
limerick_list.text:
For a ciggy I'd give my right arm.
Yes, I know smoking's doing me harm,
But there's nought like a drag
On a big, full-strength fag;
So please, spare me your cries of alarm.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
There's an order to fees you collect.
Get them straight 'cause they're bound to be checked.
You at first may earn bash cash,
Then later there's ash cash,
And more in between, I suspect.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Play this ode on the flute and euphonium,
As I sing to the word carpogonium.
Consider, I beg,
In some seaweed, each egg
Is a gonad. There's no pandemonium.

limerick_list.author: petersbuck
limerick_list.text:
Columbus — a capital city!
And if you've never been, that's a pity.
A "cowtown" no more,
It's got all but a shore.
Close your eyes, and imagine it's pretty.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
I'm autistic, a puzzle to some.
I'm not "Rain Man," retarded, or dumb.
Though I'm different, indeed,
I'm not someone you need
Tell your children to stay away from.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
From these shrubs I have picked a large stack:
Highbush huckleberries—purplish black,
And delightfully edible.
Their flavor's incredible
In a pie, or with cream, as a snack.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
How euphoriant, dear, just to hear ya!
Your look and your looks, they endear ya
To me.  It's euphoria
Seeing, dear, more o' ya —
Just being, Victoria, near ya!

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
You call in to a radio show;
You call in all the debts people owe.
Is our language confusing?
My solution's amusing:
Just call in the experts—they'll know!

limerick_list.author: proof
limerick_list.text:
Our dear brother resides as God's guest —
Eternal, forever, at rest.
But we know all too  well
That he's destined for Hell
Thanks to blasphemous thoughts he expressed.

limerick_list.author: PGS
limerick_list.text:
Engineering: the art that makes use
Of know-how to safely produce
All the things we can sell
To live healthy and well…
Or the science of nature's abuse?

limerick_list.author: speedysnail
limerick_list.text:
The convict was ashen and grey;
He was due for a lashin' that day,
And a dozen, he knew,
Could be, once they were through,
Twenty-five here in Botany Bay.

limerick_list.author: Jacqui Brown
limerick_list.text:
I'm amazed at his boundless capacity
For truth-stretching! Downright mendacity!
His facts' elasticity
And inauthenticity
Give reason to doubt his veracity.

limerick_list.author: Bob Dvorak
limerick_list.text:
I awoke around quarter to one.
Looked around, thinking, Where is my son?
In First Class! He's up grabbin'
Free snacks from that cabin.
He's toast when they find what he's done.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
An Indian's groin takes a knock,
Leaving ducts so engorged they're a shock.
His physician suspects
He has bullous effects.
"Them's my Seminole vesicles, doc!"

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
I could tell that she had a French bed.
It had scrolls at the foot and the head.
(In the bedstead, I mean.)
She seemed sweetly serene.
'Neath the blanket the lady was dead.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
She was born with three teats, one distendable.
When surgeons explained, "That's not mendable,"
She said, "Call me a rube,
But I'd say a third boob
That's extendible's truly commendable!"

limerick_list.author: Sussexdownsman
limerick_list.text:
A request from the trenches in France—
"Reinforcements: we're going to advance!"
By the time it got through
It said, "Send (from HQ)
"Three and four-pence: we're going to a dance!"

limerick_list.author: Richard Stehr
limerick_list.text:
A marriage can be like a horse—
A thoroughbred running the course.
It may run very well,
At least for a spell,
But the finish line?  That's a divorce.

limerick_list.author: CruzerX
limerick_list.text:
When a Viking lacked verve as a worker,
Or the kill-rage to be a berserker,
Eating red-headed 'shrooms
Made him stark (one assumes)
Raving mad, but at least not a shirker!

limerick_list.author: Basingstoke
limerick_list.text:
The system with ten as its base
Is called decimal. But if each space
Holds a power of ten square,
That's centesimal, where
It's one hundred that's used in ten's place.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
I'm uneasy with feelings of fear
And repulsion whenever you're near.
You give me the creeps,
A sensation that keeps
Me on edge, so I try to steer clear.

limerick_list.author: Goldie
limerick_list.text:
To my students: it falls upon you
To achieve what I ask you to do.
That's your mandate, your station,
Your job, obligation —
Complain, blow it off, and you're through.

limerick_list.author: Graham Lester
limerick_list.text:
If your car were in Britain you could
Say bonnet and be understood,
But do not talk that way
If you're in East L.A.—
It's just not the right word for that hood.

limerick_list.author: Steve Ngai
limerick_list.text:
Carbon atoms define a.m.u.
But the gram-mass is standardized too.
By their ratio, thus set,
We acknowledge our debt
To this scientist's chemical view.

limerick_list.author: StephenGold
limerick_list.text:
A young Chinese chef, name of Zhao,
Was addicted to using  cacao.
Big Li, the town mobster,
Was served chocolate lobster.
Like the dish, chef's now "off" — don't ask hao!

limerick_list.author: Jane Auerbach
limerick_list.text:
An affair always starts with the thrill
Of passion and lust and goodwill.
But in time, when lust fades
(In a month or decades),
It can end in a real Arctic chill.

limerick_list.author: Mary
limerick_list.text:
Merry Mercy, the wife of Jack Sprat,
For her diet could eat only fat;
Conversely,  the lean
Suited Jack—with a clean
Plate between them, a mercy, no spat!

limerick_list.author: Thomas Taylor
limerick_list.text:
At a shoot out, the cops — held at bay —
Called, 'Surrender! Come out now — okay?'
But the answer to that
Was a swift RAT-TAT-TAT,
And some bullet holes spelling 'NO WAY!'

limerick_list.author: Roger Vick
limerick_list.text:
There's one thing I can say without fear,
And elucidate plainly, my dear:
There are words, now passe,
Of no value today,
And dilucidate's one—that is clear.

limerick_list.author: jojo
limerick_list.text:
By bosses they're frequently prized,
Though by colleagues they're often despised—
Those sly apple-polishers,
Hard work abolishers,
Suck-ups, as workers disguised.

limerick_list.author: GaZoom
limerick_list.text:
A fata bromosa consists
Of a "wall" up ahead in the mists:
A mirage in full view
That a ship can sail through.
It's a fog bank where no fog exists.

limerick_list.author: a.groovymind
limerick_list.text:
Though the French are renowned for cuisine,
They don't head the world list of 'most clean'.
 Still, it came as a shock
When I  learned (It's no crock!)
A French swimming pool's called a 'piss scene'.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Said a nurse, "He's a geosphere." Why?
On your knowledge of English rely.
Geo signifies "dirt."
Sphere means "ball," I assert.
You can see what she thinks of this guy.

limerick_list.author: psheil
limerick_list.text:
What we have is a gillaroo trout,
And its stomach is what we're about.
Some pro-science wizard
Has named it the gizzard.
You think it's a joke? Have no doubt!

limerick_list.author: Sussexdownsman
limerick_list.text:
With ectopia cordis the heart
Forms outside (maybe all, maybe part)
Of the body. Some die;
Birth mortality's high,
And time's short if some treatment's to start.

limerick_list.author: Bill Middleton
limerick_list.text:
Did you hear of the bigamist who
Once married two women I knew?
I declared to his face,
"That's an utter disgrace,
For you can't have Kate and Edith, too."

limerick_list.author: Scott Campisi
limerick_list.text:
Two goths down in South Transylvania
With acute cacodemonomania
Now are under arrest,
But they swear they're possessed
By a devil at large in their crania.

limerick_list.author: skipjordan
limerick_list.text:
My domain is named diggers.com—
It'll save you a bundle on Mom.
When you shop, choose her casket
To fill your e-basket;
Buy a "Dummies" book, How to Embalm.

limerick_list.author: skipjordan
limerick_list.text:
It sounds like a freight train to me.
Had the naval guns answered our plea?
As the shell rumbled by
Huddled troops gave a cry —
Deep supporting fire came from the sea.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
With an approbatory expression,
You sanctioned my writing obsession.
Now you think it's a curse
That I've settled on verse
As my 24/7 profession.

limerick_list.author: speedysnail
limerick_list.text:
"Carn Hawthorn! Carn Hodge! Carn the Hawks!"
Is the way that a barracker talks;
When the footy-mad fool's
Got a craving for Rules,
"Carn the ref!" is the last thing he squawks.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
Can they prove global warming?  They can't.
Still, "The science is settled," they rant.
Stating "facts" (unreliable,
Unverifiable
Data) will get you a grant.

limerick_list.author: S. A. McBurnie
limerick_list.text:
They're balsam and turpentine's source;
Their wood many whittlers endorse,
And at Yuletide their green
In our homes may be seen.
(Yep, they're Abies: fir trees, of course.)

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
After sawing the logs into balks,
We'll be cutting the planks to the chalks.
There's a heavy demand
For this wood at the strand,
Where they've planned to build oceanside walks.

limerick_list.author: Chuck Folkers
limerick_list.text:
In my Halloween Graveyard of Doom,
I've constructed a large haunted tomb,
And in front, in a pot,
Is a big bloody clot
That is technically known as a grume.

limerick_list.author: Sussexdownsman
limerick_list.text:
Three old folks fast asleep in a row,
Doing nothing, with nowhere to go.
Since their number is three,
We've a hat trick, you see.
Geriatric I'd say! Ho ho ho.

limerick_list.author: Workshop
limerick_list.text:
My email account holds my emails,
Which were written by customers. Females
Or males are my clients
From nature and science.
Also youngsters, who send me some wee mails.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
Does English have too much complexity,
Having ten-dollar words like devexity?
With profound instructivity,
You expound, "It's declivity"—
Which increases my growing perplexity.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Caveman Dana was brooding—face twisted:
"I've studied deep time, which consisted
Of billions of years
In the past, it appears.
I insist it's before I existed!"

limerick_list.author: Dr. Work
limerick_list.text:
Americans eat 'round the clock.
We're fat and we're sick—what a shock!
If we don't take the car,
We can't get very far.
Thank God for two Subways per block!

limerick_list.author: mrsrev
limerick_list.text:
I know one of the reindeer is Dancer,
Who helps pull the sleigh with dear Prancer.
Are they light on their feet?
Are they graceful and fleet?
Are they dancers? Do you know the answer?

limerick_list.author: James Dobson
limerick_list.text:
She's a goal-directed (purposive) gal
Talking weddings and grammar with Hal:
"We'll be saying I will,
But I'm arguing, still,
That, instead, we should go with I shall."

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
Cloudcuckooland: that's your mentality,
Utopian irrationality.
Don't be naive.
You're a fool to believe
She'd go out with you.  Dude, face reality.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
I'm a decadent bastard, they say.
"Self-indulgence and moral decay
Are his life. He's no good!"
Would I change if I could?
And sing hymns in the choir? No way!

limerick_list.author: GalFisk
limerick_list.text:
A helmet's required for work
In industrial settings. Some jerk
May drop bolts on your head,
But that hard hat, instead,
Takes the brunt of the blow. What a perk!

limerick_list.author: Len Farano
limerick_list.text:
Two cute teachers who taught kids from farms
(Sleeveless dresses enhanced all their charms)
Were told their attire
Sets young boys on fire—
"You do not have the right to bare arms!"

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
Catching game fish: yes, that is my aim.
Doesn't matter what type: it's the same,
Be they marlin or pike,
Salt or fresh — all I like.
(Of course, game fish don't call it a game.)

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
John's seduction of Edna was swift.
He had hit a home run. (Get my drift?)
Women always would flock
To this guy 'round the clock.
"It's my nature," he says. "It's a gift."

limerick_list.author: Jeff Foster
limerick_list.text:
The dissimulative nobleman, Niles,
Has the following thought as he smiles:
"One must always seem pleasant
Whilst whipping a peasant—
Another of life's little trials."

limerick_list.author: Chris Young
limerick_list.text:
Prepositions show role, link in space.
In some languages, what takes their place
Is, say, how a word ends.
To translate "Dine with friends",
Put your friends in the comitative case.

limerick_list.author: J. E. Pettit
limerick_list.text:
When you're chasing the dragon, it's true
You can die from the high you pursue.
Fight its fiery breath,
For the dragon is death.
Slay it first, or the dragon slays you.

limerick_list.author: StephenGold
limerick_list.text:
When our clergyman, Reverend Gray,
Felt compelled in his sermon to say
God had told him that prayer
Was just so much hot air,
He was spirited swiftly away.

limerick_list.author: Graig Gigol
limerick_list.text:
A bankrupt store-owner named Bevan
Had died and was taken to Heaven,
But his heirs didn't stop;
They re-opened the shop,
Which they named "Chapter 7-11".

limerick_list.author: Tim Alborn
limerick_list.text:
In Leeds, where I first saw The Who,
They were shakin' all over—it's true!
All their songs were so pulsant,
An anticonvulsant
Was surely a tad overdue.

limerick_list.author: JimInRoses
limerick_list.text:
With the aim to assist one another,
The Land of the Free and its Mother
Made a pact that, we see,
Launched the B.I.O.T.
For one island, whose culture they'd smother.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
A nut and a bolt were pursuing
Quite an ill-augered effort at screwing.
The drill-bit, instead,
Hit the nail on the head
When he said, "What a tool! What's he's doing?"

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
A caruncle is fleshy; it droops,
Like the wattles of hens in the coops,
Or the comb of a cock—
He's the chicken-coop jock,
And the layer of layers in groups.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Am I crinated? Well, yes and no.
On my noggin, there's not much to show,
Yet there's clearly no lack
Of dark hair on my back
(Not to mention that spot "down below").

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
To do craftwork, you'd best understand
You must make every item by hand,
But the craftwork produced
Gives your ego a boost
As your fame and your fortune expand.

limerick_list.author: Goldie
limerick_list.text:
I gave you the shirt off my back;
You're not worth it — you phony, you quack.
So now I am shirtless
And you're still desertless —
You really deserve a good smack.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Beef shin, also known as the shank,
Is a cheap cut of meat, nothing swank.
It's the kind you might use
For your slow-cooking stews—
One more reason we've Bessie to thank.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Bread for sandwiches (white or whole wheat),
Pasta, vegetables, all kinds of meat,
Chicken (whole, wings, or thighs),
Frozen pizza, pot pies—
All are groceries, stuff that you eat.

This term also includes things like soap,
Mr. Clean, Brillo, Pampers, and Scope,
And like items you'd buy
From some grocer-type guy,
So a car, horse, or rocketship? Nope.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
Here's my counterconditioning tool:
I've been swimming each day in the pool
To help conquer the fear
(Idiotic, it's clear)
That I'll drown in a bucket of drool.

limerick_list.author: matthewg
limerick_list.text:
I'm quite fond of a plant-killing spree.
Though a pro, I would murder for free.
When I find a fish tank
Which with algae is rank,
Adding algicide gives me much glee.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
My new volume with foldouts of Rome
Is unwieldy and craves its own home.
Normal size is exceeded;
A book cradle's needed
For display and to page through this tome.

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
These are crenate leaves, here on this hedge.
See their curvy 'teeth' round each leaf's edge?
It's as if they'd been cut
Using pinking shears, but
Leaving scallops, not points, I'd allege.

limerick_list.author: Meg Beagle
limerick_list.text:
When I pick up my bow and my arrow,
I'm thrilled to my sinews and marrow.
Archery's the name
Of my favorite game—
Fine, feathered, and fit for a Pharaoh.

limerick_list.author: Carl Lands
limerick_list.text:
As porter, take in what one offers
At temple and guard against scoffers.
Asuppim can earn ya
An unholy hernia,
So work two by two in the coffers.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
These expatriate delicatessens
Teach behavior-based, usable lessons:
Though folks move far away,
Tastes of home every day
Fend off homesickness—foods can be blessin's.

limerick_list.author: Mad Kane
limerick_list.text:
"Do not argue with me," said the dad
To his son, who was making him mad.
"You are too disputatious.
Your point is fallacious
And..." "Huh?" said the four-year-old lad.

limerick_list.author: Roger Vick
limerick_list.text:
Edward III, in his fifty year reign,
Was a bane to the French; his campaign
Launched the Hundred Years War,
While the government swore,
Never more! Your taxation's a strain.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
"Due to diageotropism, plants
Spread outward, not upward," he rants.
"But its function's still muddy
And needs further study.
I've applied for some government grants."

limerick_list.author: Ulfras
limerick_list.text:
This profession, a bit of a fad,
Uses smells to heal sickness and SAD,
Which is great, as it goes,
But my eyes, not my nose,
Read "aroma-the-rapist"...that's bad!

limerick_list.author: Janet McConnaughey
limerick_list.text:
Since at cleaning old bones he's the best, he's
The curator's pet. (She's confessed he's
One who must be confined,
Else she'll find that he's dined
On her finest displays.) He's Dermestes.

limerick_list.author: JimInRoses
limerick_list.text:
Cytogeny comes on in spells,
As a growth spurt that suddenly swells
All the bits that were smaller —
You also get taller —
Because of the forming of cells.

limerick_list.author: sigg
limerick_list.text:
A Mayan tattooist might start
With prayers to this god of his art.
He then will begin
By breaking the skin
And inking a bare body part.

limerick_list.author: TrossL
limerick_list.text:
His bike was seen leaving the path,
And they say he was seething with wrath.
When the body was found,
Its spine had been bound—
He's a bookbinder! You do the math.

limerick_list.author: Goldie
limerick_list.text:
Everlasting peace — phantom dream for mankind!
But here's something you're likely to find:
It's the everlasting pea;
Rose-pink flowers you'll see.
May this colorful vine cheer your mind.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
Young Queen Constance had cheated and got
Into bed with her footman — a lot.
"Such acts must be deterred!"
Raged the king.  So the bird
Was today exemplarily shot.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Though a carman is found in a car,
A carboy is different by far.
It's the large, bulky vessel
In the lab you might wrestle,
While acids you pour from this jar.

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
For case-management, courts hold a callover,
So fewer proceedings will fall over.
Judges sit on the bench and
All matters get mentioned.
Ho hum, but by lunchtime it's all over.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
The bobsledders push at the top
As they sprint to the edge of the drop.
Then they zoom down the ice
And ignore a device
Called the brake, 'cause they know they can't stop.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle and PGS
limerick_list.text:
Couette flow of oil in a bearing
Inhibits—by shearing—the wearing:
Eccentric, small gaps
Will avoid making scraps
From its fast-spinning trunnions by tearing.

limerick_list.author: Jean McEwen
limerick_list.text:
As the two were becoming acquainted,
Their very first meeting was tainted
'Cause Nan lost her nerve
And her knees gave a swerve.
She feared fainting so much that she fainted.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
She deals in the deepest abstraction
While he's barely mastered subtraction.
They're like night and day,
Yet together they stay.
I just don't understand the attraction.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
I have come down the pike, as you see,
On my Harley, as fast as can be.
Who should come down the pike —
Just appears — on his bike?
A state cop who's been following me.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
Have a burger with cheese on your diet?
You're breaking me up—you're a riot!
Guess I misunderstood,
But that did my heart good.
You were kidding, of course; don't deny it.

limerick_list.author: Ruchiccio
limerick_list.text:
The cockroach is scared of the rat
Who, in turn, is afraid of the cat,
Who dreads dogs, who fear men,
Who avoid wives... (it then
Comes full circle)... who screech, "Roaches! Scat!"

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
The drum major led the brass band
As it marched down the Strand. Understand:
As a rule he was graceful,
But he'd just drunk a caseful
Of ale. His performance was panned.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
The term bra-burner's just a cheap shot
That a feminist hears quite a lot
From the men who say she,
As a gal, shouldn't be
In the workplace. (They're wrong and she's not.)

limerick_list.author: Julia
limerick_list.text:
A politico's famed common touch
To his critics means not very much.
Those 4 Cs for a trim
Might reveal more of him
Than intended. He's outed, as such.

limerick_list.author: Janet McConnaughey
limerick_list.text:
When I'm brewing some coffee to quaff,
Every cup-marking on the carafe
Measures half of a mug
Of my donzerlee drug.
Six-ounce coffee cups? Hah. It's to laugh.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
The blue riband is Patrick's, and that's
Why his ladyfriends shouted "Congrats!"
He's a breeder of felines.
The judges made beelines
To congratulate Pat and his cats.

limerick_list.author: Chuck Folkers
limerick_list.text:
With billingsgate, Cheney let loose
(In No Uncertain Terms) his abuse.
He felt better, he stressed,
Having tried to suggest
How the senator might reproduce.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
From whence cometh this term is unknown,
But dog bee's a name for a drone.
While all workers are female,
This indolent bee-male
Is idle till bride flights are flown.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
The Amboy Dukes rocked with their sound,
But alas, just one hit came around:
They were looking to enter
The cognitive center,
And number 16's what they found.

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
Strictly speaking, districtly's distinct.
It's not strictly, although they are linked,
As they mean the same thing.
Nonetheless, here's the sting:
In all districts, districtly's extinct.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
Are my daughter's eyes brown? More like black,
As an iris, for her, is a lack.
Yes, from birth, my sweet Lydia
Has had aniridia:
No iris at Dad looking back.

limerick_list.author: Frank Luke
limerick_list.text:
Willy's wont to parade in the nude,
Thinks he's special, a really cool dude.
Thinks he's buff and so hot,
But the fact is he's not.
He affronts and his backside's (yuck!) lewd.

limerick_list.author: Ulfras
limerick_list.text:
Apocryphal, one could construe,
Means "spurious, doubtful, untrue."
Yet why, while the Bible
Is gospel, not libel,
Is the Apocrypha seen as askew?

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
When medicine's evidence-based,
It's effective—no fraud, little waste
(So authorities state),
And I think it's just great.
Bogus claims and quack cures are replaced.

limerick_list.author: splendiferous
limerick_list.text:
That functions have args it is clear,
And the args yield results that cohere.
But bugs that have smitten
The code you have written
Give rise to behavior most queer.

limerick_list.author: Mary
limerick_list.text:
If you find there's some sand in your chowder,
Don't assume that it's seasoning powder;
It's from clams that the cook
Didn't clean, so don't brook
Such abuse in your soup. Just yell louder.

limerick_list.author: Virge
limerick_list.text:
Apophasis: I'll never say
That it means giving secrets away
When, by slip or pretension,
You casually mention
The things that you shouldn't betray.

limerick_list.author: SusanL
limerick_list.text:
Graduation day, life has begun
For my couch-bound directionless son.
He says, "Mom, take a pill
I've got time now to chill.
I'll make plans when I'm done having fun."

limerick_list.author: mike scholtes
limerick_list.text:
If a musical amp's overdriven,
Then distortion of sounds is a given.
The waveforms are clipped,
Looking flat-topped and snipped,
And both speakers and ears may be riven.

limerick_list.author: PGS
limerick_list.text:
When Bunsen and Kirchhoff, the two
First spectroscopists, saw it they knew:
The element, newly
Discovered, shines bluely;
They named it Cs, for "sky-blue".

limerick_list.author: Frank Luke
limerick_list.text:
To concoct a banana split: cut
Fruit in half (ice cream filling the rut),
Pile on cream whipped up swell,
Drizzle syrup as well,
And then top with a cherry or nut!!

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
"Don't you look at a king!  You're a cat!
Straight ahead's where your eyes should be at!"
"I can look where I please!
I'm as good as you!  Jeez!"
"It's latrine duty, son, just for that!"

limerick_list.author: JimInRoses
limerick_list.text:
A dimwit's a kind of a dunce
Who's careless of slurs and affronts,
For his wits are too slow
For the import to go
Past his ears when they're said only once.

limerick_list.author: Kuranui
limerick_list.text:
When hearing deep-sea orchestration,
There's nothing, in my estimation,
As good as the whale;
Its glorious scale
Truly makes it a singing cetacean.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle and turnip
limerick_list.text:
What's a beemaster know about? Drones.
And a bellmaster? Carillon tones.
A brewmaster? Ales.
And a bandmaster? Scales.
You've bemastered those subjects! (She groans.)

limerick_list.author: Qermaq
limerick_list.text:
When I tear something made out of crepe,
I have one chosen way to reshape
What I've ruined. I swear,
Such allegiance is rare!
Yes, I am an adherer to tape!

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Tell me, how do you spell ankylosis?
It is A-N-C-H-Y-L-osis.
But there's no k in sight.
Could it really be right?
(English spelling can lead to psychosis!)

limerick_list.author: PGS
limerick_list.text:
It is called the "Frankonian crown",
The citadel over the town
Of Coburg on Itz,
With its sightseeing hits
And its ducally lasting renown.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Clara Bow, as she puts on her sweater,
Purrs softly, "I've never had better."
'Round my finger she's curled
In my fantasy world.
(In real life? No, I never have met her.)

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
As long as you're male, and alive, it's
A tenet you'll need to survive.  It's
Not polite to go bare,
So at least you must wear
A breechcloth to cover your privates.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
The aphtha's a little white spot
In your mouth. You won't like it a lot.
You have thrush (sounds absurd)—
The disease, not the bird—
It's a fungal infection you've got.

limerick_list.author: JimInRoses
limerick_list.text:
This pizza is less than delectable;
The base should be barely detectable —
Much crisper and thinner —
When served for my dinner.
Don't you know that the dough is depectible?

limerick_list.author: Bob Dvorak
limerick_list.text:
"Has the bishop a few moments free?
There is something I'd like him to see."
"The chancery brass
Are all off at Mass.
He'll be back in the office at three."

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Seeking mole rats, I'm looking for traces.
Cryptozoic, they live in those places
Where, secluded, they're biding,
So fully in hiding,
We can't get a look at their faces.

limerick_list.author: timon
limerick_list.text:
Our system is strict: dirigiste;
And those who contribute the least
Are officially placed
(For avoidance of waste)
In category D.*
___________
* For "deceased".

limerick_list.author: Bob Dvorak
limerick_list.text:
This dumb tool, you damn fool, has you stuck.
Then my dad took a look, and said, "Buck?
You never will tighten
That drill bit you're fightin'
If you don't find the key for the chuck."

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
As the chef in the restaurant knows,
The beluga is old, and it shows.
For a food that's a tempter,
It's caviar emptor:
Beware of those secondhand roes!

limerick_list.author: lopey
limerick_list.text:
The Day that is called April Fools'
Causes some to become unkind tools.
Their practical gags
Are sometimes such drags,
For on April the First, there's no rules.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
Now it's leggings embroidered with fruits,
And that hair, and those polka-dot boots—
She's all pigtails and pinks;
Don't know what that girl thinks.
Man has she got a case of the cutes!

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
The matador's sword tip descended,
Taking life from the bull, as intended.
To the crowd's loud hurrahs,
Came the thrust—coup de grace.
At that deathblow, it mercifully ended.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
To arbalesters your hats you should doff.
I'm no suck-up, so please do not scoff.
These are fellows whose skill
With a crossbow can kill,
Not the sort that you'd care to piss off.

limerick_list.author: skipjordan
limerick_list.text:
My man Spike is  not really too swift,
And his focus will wander and drift.
You could say he's a dolt,
But just hand him a bolt—
To join wood is his God-given gift.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
I've gone everyplace I've wished to go —
To all regions, save one, as you know:
I've wished from the start
To visit your heart,
But wishing does not make it so.

limerick_list.author: Jacqui Brown
limerick_list.text:
"Xerostomia," doctors opined,
"Dry mouth of a troublesome kind.
It's been known to deprive a
Poor guy of saliva,
Like  desiccants' drying, you'll find."

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Just last month I insured Auntie Nell.
Now I'll disinsure Nelly as well:
Wax her stairs, cut her brakes,
Do whatever it takes
To consign that old biddy to Hell.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
For once I'm excusably late;
I was zapped by the finger of fate.
First, I got a flat tire,
Then I stepped in deep mire…
Now my pants are on fire?  That's just great!

limerick_list.author: Roger Dunn
limerick_list.text:
There are exits that end with no pang
Of remorse, or a knell's muffled clang.
Thus this chapter I'll shut
Not with whispering, but
An explosive, loud noise called a bang!

limerick_list.author: Len Farano
limerick_list.text:
Cara's ancestry's quite hard to tell.
Did her DNA test not go well?
She sent in a little
Clear vial with her spittle,
But the lab couldn't track Cara's cell.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Dissatisfaction is what you might feel
At the end of a poorly cooked meal,
Or when you discover
The ring from your lover
Was made with a stone that's not real.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
The Cardinals, a team in St. Louis,
In '06 brought a championship to us.
With the highest regards,
We all bellowed, "Go Cards!"
While permitting the owners to screw us.

limerick_list.author: J. E. Pettit
limerick_list.text:
The celebrity-worshipping sod
Has a viewpoint theistically odd:
The sad ignoramus
Thinks anyone famous
Should surely be treated like God.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
Taking Caduet daily, I know
My cholesterol levels are low.
Made by Pfizer, it's new—
Not just one drug, but two!
It's a modern-day medicine show.

limerick_list.author: Bill Middleton
limerick_list.text:
What a navel encounter last spring
Occurred between daddy Ben Sing
And his daughter, Sue Ann,
All about a young man
And her new belly button gold ring.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
An ambsace, I'm here to assert,
Is like lint that might cling to your shirt.
It's the least you can count
Of the smallest amount
Of a substance as worthless as dirt.

limerick_list.author: zqms
limerick_list.text:
You know soot? That's black carbon and air,
A potentially fatal affair
If inhaled. This black muck
Can come out of your truck,
When it's backfiring, therefore take care.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
Some counterreformers are those
Who had pushed for a change, but propose,
After upticks in crimes,
We return to the times
Of the past, 'cause the bloom's off the rose.

limerick_list.author: Goldie
limerick_list.text:
When I thunk my big toe on a rock
There's a moment of shouting and shock.
But I'm glad, I'm not pissed —
It confirms I exist.
I can hop around, blaspheme and squawk.

limerick_list.author: Janet McConnaughey
limerick_list.text:
Heard the news? While perusing the zoo news,
I inferred, from the purchase of blue gnus
That have masculine genes
For our wildebeest queens,
That our herd of gnus soon will have new gnus.

limerick_list.author: alan meyer
limerick_list.text:
Coal gasification would seem
To fulfill the American dream.
Yet its technical woes
Keep confounding the pros.
While we wait, let's go get some ice cream.

limerick_list.author: Workshop
limerick_list.text:
June had wanted this man, so she'd smile
At him obviously, and she'd beguile
Him. She flashed him a breast
And some parts of the rest
Of her assets: that's feminine wile.

limerick_list.author: SusanL
limerick_list.text:
We're the best in the state, unsurpassed,
And we're aiming to prove it at last.
While the other teams vie,
Our first round is a bye—
Second round we will shine (they're outclassed).

limerick_list.author: Frank Luke
limerick_list.text:
We've tried and we've tried; now we must
Think of changing our course, so we just
Should admit it's too bad—
To continue is mad;
Not defeat—let's just call it a bust.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Antiperistalsis? Oh my!
Your gut's moving backward.  Don't cry!
Use the loo; there's the door.
Please don't barf on the floor.
Though it's painful, I'm sure you won't die.

limerick_list.author: Bob Dvorak
limerick_list.text:
Though her heart wasn't totally in it,
Angelina sat down at the spinet.
Said her teacher, "Go slow.
Set the metronome so
It will tap sixty-four beats per minute."

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
Can you answer this puzzle of note?
There's a wolf, and some corn, and a goat,
And a river to cross
Without suff'ring a loss,
When there's room for just one in the boat.

limerick_list.author: Mark Mironer
limerick_list.text:
With the price of a gallon of gas,
It is finally coming to pass
That Detroit is uneasy.
Long trips leave us queasy—
America's carsick en masse.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
I believe in dark spirits ethereal;
In the mornings, my diabaterial
Gift to the gods
To improve crossing odds
As a rule is hot gruel or dry cereal.

limerick_list.author: Michael Toalster
limerick_list.text:
I'm in love, which has rotted my brain.
But I'll say it again and again:
Though you don't look so glamorous,
You make me feel amorous—
Say, garbage man, am I insane?

limerick_list.author: PGS
limerick_list.text:
In your text there's a question for you,
My dear students. You'll find this DQ
To discuss at the end
Of the chapter. Please send
Me your answer, from your point of view.

limerick_list.author: Frank Hubeny
limerick_list.text:
A tobacco called burley is grown
In Kentucky, air-cured, and it's known
For its light-colored leaves.
The bright life-slayer weaves
Through the smoke a dark cough that's your own.

limerick_list.author: David
limerick_list.text:
Tarzan roared as he soared and swung free
After dumping poor Jane in the tree,
But the hollering fellow
Had reason to bellow:
He urgently needed to pee.

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
"This one's packed full of functions," the clerk
Says, "It chops..." (rather irksome, this jerk)
"And it blends, mixes, dices,
Grinds, grates, peels and slices".
(So it's functional. But — does it work?)

limerick_list.author: zqms
limerick_list.text:
My old teddy can feel me, I swear!
Only vaguely, perhaps, but this bear
(Like all of his species)
Possesses estheses:
There are basic sensations in there.

limerick_list.author: Roger Vick
limerick_list.text:
At first just a fanciful dream,
It then crystallized into a scheme.
From naught but a notion
To planned locomotion:
An engine for harnessing steam.

limerick_list.author: Tim Alborn
limerick_list.text:
A thistle was going to seed,
So I tugged at this troublesome weed.
When I snapped it, some sap
Landed splat on my lap.
It snapped back: "When you prick us, we bleed!"

limerick_list.author: birdbarf
limerick_list.text:
A bomblet's a small bomb, they say.
And a boomlet?  A small boom, okay?
If a bomblet goes boom,
Can we safely assume
That a boomlet is coming our way?

limerick_list.author: Bob Dvorak
limerick_list.text:
"It's a car, for land's sakes, darling Harriet,
A model of beauty, this chariot.
Don't grudge the long hours —
I don't bring it flowers;
It's my love but I'm not gonna marry it!"

limerick_list.author: alan meyer
limerick_list.text:
An ampulla? A flask made of glass.
And?  A cruet that priests use in Mass.
Now, since Jack there in back
Answered "membranous sac",
He will move to the head of the class.

limerick_list.author: mrsrev
limerick_list.text:
Devilled eggs, devilled crab, devilled ham;
If you'd like, you could serve devilled Spam.
Have a devilled buffet—
You could try, anyway,
With some duck, or some lamb, or some clam.

limerick_list.author: SusanL
limerick_list.text:
Rooster Rob, who is cock of the walk,
Tries impressing the hens of the flock;
He likes sculpting his dome
To ensure that his comb
Has the splendor to square with his squawk.

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
As I've got my pawns into a mess,
I can see that my queen can't progress.
Behind their ranks, serried,
She's trapped. She's a buried
Piece. King? He's exposed. Such is chess.

limerick_list.author: Carole Lyons
limerick_list.text:
Teenage acne left scars on Louise,
Who popped pimples throughout her disease.
At her boyfriend's persuasion,
She tried dermabrasion.
The surgeon is now her main squeeze.

limerick_list.author: Janet McConnaughey
limerick_list.text:
Though her share of the bounty is scant,
The ergate, the tough worker ant,
Grubs for food. She gets blisters
Feeding Mom and her sisters,
Never tells the fat queen, "No, I can't."

limerick_list.author: speedysnail
limerick_list.text:
In Britain, the letters F.C.
Stand for football club (soccer): e.g.,
Aston Villa or Reading.
If you're thinking of heading...
I bet you're a club devotee.

limerick_list.author: Janet McConnaughey
limerick_list.text:
The Dandy's great Desperate Dan
Spurns caviare, tournedos and flan.
He eats cow pies for strength —
Cows in crusts, at their length,
Horns and all. He's the world's strongest man.

limerick_list.author: mike scholtes
limerick_list.text:
On a glacier, the line of the firn
Is a subtle locale to discern.
It's where alimentation
Succumbs to ablation —
A balance where futures may turn.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Willie's foolish and dazed—he's assot.
He's enraptured like I don't know what.
Nell's assotted him well
And, as near I can tell,
Before long they'll be tying the knot.

limerick_list.author: Beverley Sharp
limerick_list.text:
I'm beleaguered by armies of ants.
I retreat as their columns advance.
For I fear that I'll find that
These ants are the kind that
Perchance like to occupy pants.

limerick_list.author: Comicoffee
limerick_list.text:
I hate broccoli—what a foul veggie!
Thoughts of eating it make me feel edgy.
Said my bro, "Here's a crown.
Better swallow it down!
If you don't, be prepared for a wedgie!"

limerick_list.author: Roger Dunn
limerick_list.text:
"If the level's wrong, how would I know?"
"There's a reference point painted to show
Where the level should be.
Here's the line! Can't you see?
Datum level's its name. It's too low!"

limerick_list.author: Bill Cernansky
limerick_list.text:
One ten-billionth, when shaved from a meter
Gives an angstrom. If you throw your heater,
That baseball could go
Say, a trillion or so,
If it's hit by New York's Derek Jeter.

limerick_list.author: psheil
limerick_list.text:
He's a consummate, sly politician;
If you argue, to win's his ambition.
With a face like a gerbil,
He's an acrobat, verbal,
And he'll rapidly change his position.

limerick_list.author: timon
limerick_list.text:
Though it's one of the finest of fishes,
This conger eel frequently wishes
That its name, Conger conger,
Had been even longer;
It's planning to breed a subspecies.

limerick_list.author: Carl Lands
limerick_list.text:
Let your plowshares be beat into swords;
Make of pruninghooks spears for the hordes.
When a roar like a lion
Pounds holy Mount Zion,
You'll know that it's wholly the Lord's.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Colonitis? I've got it, alas,
And my buddies berate me en masse.
In the chatrooms they post
That I'm self-diagnosed
Since my head's firmly stuck up my ass.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Whenever you're buying a pair
Of sunglasses, always take care
That a firm guarantee
Says they screen out UV
And they're treated to be antiglare.

limerick_list.author: Richard English
limerick_list.text:
A rooster's a Yank's name for cock;
He's the chicken who's head of the flock.
If you think cock's a curse word,
Consider the worse word
I call them around 5 o'clock.

limerick_list.author: Len Farano
limerick_list.text:
As for free-range, I don't give a damn.
It just sounds like a marketing scam.
To keep piggies unpenned
Is humane? In the end,
Every hog's bound for bacon and ham.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
Abolitionary fervor arose
In the North among folks who were foes
Of the owners of slaves—
Those fanatical knaves
In the South causing Africans' woes.

limerick_list.author: skipjordan
limerick_list.text:
The notices stirred some distress,
'Cause my tending to bills is a    mess.
Wrote the bank,  "We'll take back
Your new get-away shack.
Send past dues via mail that's express."

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
"He's articulate, bright, and so clean.
That's a storybook.  Know what I mean?"
With that "clean" remark, Joe
Meant Obama is no
Vulgar rapper whose mouth's a latrine.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
"What's that stuff on your face, Grace?" "It's powder,
Expensive, but chic makes me prouder.
Though the price isn't tiny,
My nose isn't shiny.
I'll laud Estée Lauder still louder."

limerick_list.author: Jacqui Brown
limerick_list.text:
In Ibsen, my friend is a dabbler,
But she's also a snoop and a babbler.
I remember the day
When we went to a play
And she gossiped throughout Hedda Gabler.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
A dessert apple's one you don't bake,
But eat raw, although make no mistake:
While an apple a day
For dessert is OK,
Even doctors prefer chocolate cake.

limerick_list.author: Virge
limerick_list.text:
Election time comes, and I flee.
Now tell me, sir, why should this be?
No details can be told
With counting by Diebold:
Abroad, I can vote absentee.

limerick_list.author: Ruchiccio
limerick_list.text:
"May I clonally copy you, Delph?"
Asks the magical scientist elf.
I reply with a no
Since it's ethically low—
I don't think I could live with myself.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
The problems are getting immense;
You refuse to take sides — that, I sense.
Just decide which side's right
And unite, join the fight!
Do not straddle, son — get off the fence!

limerick_list.author: AndrewB
limerick_list.text:
No two Cabbage Patch Kids are the same,
And each one of them has its own name.
These Coleco-made toys
Were for girls and for boys.
They brought Xavier Roberts great fame.

limerick_list.author: Ruchiccio
limerick_list.text:
My short friend now resembles a ball;
She's so chubby. Now had she been tall,
She would not look so dumpy.
"Look who's gotten all plumpy!"
"I'm vertically challenged, that's all."

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
A bone-house resides in a tomb:
It's a coffin (a skeleton's room).
It is also your bod,
That live osseous pod;
Or a charnel-house (death-whiff of doom).

limerick_list.author: Tim Alborn
limerick_list.text:
Since 666 they've been parking
Their Saxon remains here in Barking,
Just east of East Ham—
And I'll give you a dram
For resisting all canine-remarking.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
That's a bugle call: short, brassy tune.
Preteen Jack learned to play one last June.
Every morning that devil, 'e
Loves to play Reveille —
Waking us all:  his "platoon".

limerick_list.author: SusanL and Michael Toalster
limerick_list.text:
Since the judge snuffed my scheme with his gavel,
All my dreams have begun to unravel.
He curtailed my mean plan
To sell bombs in Iran:
I am now serving life, and can't travel!

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
When two silk larvae sing the same tune,
There's a doupion—double cocoon.
When the two interweave,
I have heard and believe,
Silkworm breeders don't find it a boon.

limerick_list.author: Tim Alborn
limerick_list.text:
Again-sayers never repeat
What another guy utters. They greet
Each assertion with sneering
And bellicose jeering:
Disdainful complaining's their beat.

limerick_list.author: Gtmac
limerick_list.text:
Whenever the dextrous succeed,
I'm unable to follow their lead.
These big clumsy hands
Destroy all my plans.
I'm a ham-fisted oaf, guaranteed.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
As an agent, I'm totally sold
On this comic who's breaking the mold.
Clever jokes, rapid wit—
Let me tell you, he's it!
Without doubt, this guy's comedy gold.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
If I say that a steak is aflame,
I am making a serious claim.
I assert it's incinerating,
And losing its dinner-rating.
Afire means exactly the same.

limerick_list.author: AndrewB
limerick_list.text:
Ajiaco in Cuba is stew.
And it's also like stew in Peru.
In Colombia, though,
It is soup. And I know
In Peru, they put chilies in, too.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
An aspartate transaminase test
Is performed at your doctor's request.
If it shows that increased
AST's been released
In your blood, then your organs are stressed.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
The burqini's in fashion for chicks
Who are Muslim and quite in a fix
At the beach, where they'd sin
If they showed too much skin.
It's a swimsuit Imams shouldn't nix.

limerick_list.author: Chris Young
limerick_list.text:
Fibs my brother, "I haven't a bean."
So the cheat chooses cheap cheese cuisine.
But some finely sliced slivers
Are all he delivers.
He's cheeseparing, meaning he's mean.

limerick_list.author: David
limerick_list.text:
You should use the full colon this way:
First write that you've something to say,
Then the dots, miss a space,
And then make your brief case
Till (as here) there's no more to convey.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Old Geoffrey was very observant,
And to be a good host he was fervent.
Guest in need of a saucer?
The great author Chaucer
Called a famular in (that's a servant).

limerick_list.author: Robert Holland
limerick_list.text:
If your teenager often sounds wack,
Chill out 'cause it's prob'ly not crack.
Though his argot sounds dope,
There is reason for hope —
He rejects you, but always comes back.

limerick_list.author: Paperdragon
limerick_list.text:
Dihydrogen monoxide I find
Often frightens the gullible mind.
Read the claims with great care
As the aim is to scare.
It's just water — the everyday kind.

limerick_list.author: mike scholtes
limerick_list.text:
Though the birders love eagle and swift,
To the coverts they've given short shrift.
Not mere covering minions
Of second-string pinions,
They're authors of airflow and lift.

limerick_list.author: Goldie
limerick_list.text:
I think I would bet even money,
When my nose becomes drippy and runny,
And stuff plops in my brew,
On my dog, or on you,
That some smart aleck says "That snot funny."

limerick_list.author: Ruchiccio
limerick_list.text:
Mike's a genius, as smart as they come. He's
Got me, birdbrained Bill, as a chum. He's
Just called me a shnook,
So I bought him a book
Called Discovering Dumbness for Dummies.

limerick_list.author: Rose and Scott Campisi
limerick_list.text:
Michael's poems are painful to see.
An OEDILFer's antithesis, he;
For he starts them with 'Tis,
Thinks iamb means he is,
And he swears that baguette rhymes with flea.

limerick_list.author: PGS
limerick_list.text:
One girl shows more skin over there
Than elsewhere whole families dare
To expose. In Brazil,
On the beach, men are still
Just amazed, and such sights make 'em stare!

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
"Class, a quiz: an ectorganism? Mick?"
"Miss, external (sick!) parasites stick,
Like (yuk!) leeches in mud:
They latch on, suck your blood."
"Very good. For your prize, here's a tick."

limerick_list.author: pöt
limerick_list.text:
I was ill-prepared, but I thought, "Damn!
Let's go in for this ruddy exam!"
I was lucky, however,
(And, luckily, clever),
So, now, an accountant I am.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
We're running the ball by design,
And our fullback keeps bucking the line.
Our ground game's on show
With just minutes to go
And us up 27 to 9.

limerick_list.author: Len Farano
limerick_list.text:
Active shooter! We're all filled with fright.
An armed gunman may soon be in sight.
This grim terror has spread
Bringing chaos and dread.
The new mantra is "Run, Hide, or Fight."

limerick_list.author: Michael Toalster and SusanL
limerick_list.text:
I'm affianced to Bess, so I still
Have to swallow the bitterest pill.
When she asked me to wed,
I was sure she said "bed",
So "I'd love to!" is now just "I will."

limerick_list.author: Sussexdownsman
limerick_list.text:
I've invented new cream for the skin —
Pure emollient, gentle and thin.
Should good business ensue,
An emolument's due
For the service I've rendered therein!

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Daisy broke Randy's heart when he found
That the bitch had been sleeping around.
He wept tears of disgust
And of pain, saying just,
"It is time you went back to the pound."

limerick_list.author: Jesse Frankovich
limerick_list.text:
All too often, discomfort's been sparked
In a man when his wife has remarked,
"While I cook, shop, and clean,
You just stare at that screen,
With your lazy ass comfortably parked!"

limerick_list.author: mrsrev
limerick_list.text:
Krakatoans will always lament
The day of the lava's descent.
O'er their homes it did crash—
All that hot rock and ash—
'Twas a true cataclysmic event!

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
A catchphrase one hears can amaze one,
So one's sometimes inclined to rephrase one.
Like that popular joke
About idiot folk,
Where it's taking a village to raise one.

limerick_list.author: Bill LaVern Kalles
limerick_list.text:
When the King (or the Queen) says it's grand
To take over some other folk's land,
A Crown Colony's chartered.
Those natives not martyred
Are ruled with a cruel iron hand.

limerick_list.author: David
limerick_list.text:
When a bottlenose whale died today,
Rugged boatmen wiped teardrops away.
Others smirked, as dolts do,
Unaware that those who
Lack compassion will make our world pay.

limerick_list.author: skipjordan
limerick_list.text:
The downsteepy hollow was chill,
And at bottom was moonshiner  Bill.
The slope was so steep
That you might have to creep,
But your jug you could fill at Bill's still.

limerick_list.author: Bluebelle
limerick_list.text:
That dazzling star is so bright,
I came out to see why it was light
When the witching hour's done
And the sunny old sun
Is asleep in the dark of the night.

limerick_list.author: Roger Vick
limerick_list.text:
Absent minded, with musings sublime,
He stepped back on the curb just in time.
Eighty-five years of age,
This spry silver-haired sage
Was so nearly cut down in his prime.

limerick_list.author: Chris Young
limerick_list.text:
This word, more archaic than old,
Is as rare and as precious as gold.
To spread round its use, I'll
Assert circumfusile
Is "spreadable round" (so I'm told).

limerick_list.author: timon
limerick_list.text:
The verses you write, I would bet,
Are the best to be found on the net.
But alas! There's no way
To make verse-writing pay;
Don't give up the day job just yet.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
While a date with Diane is a treat,
Her outlook is far from upbeat,
For Diane's anorexic
And also dyslexic,
Which means that she seldom will tea.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Said a sorceress, making a blunder,
"You've avoided my magic!" (No wonder.
Cried her classified ad:
"Charm's for sale.") That's too bad.
Hers are spells that I will not fall under.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
Loads of room in the rear to lade freight,
And I'm licensed to serve every state.
I can clear a quick buck
On the bed of my truck,
But your cargo, sir, that's tempting fate.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Our ad was from heaven—empyreal.
The imagery used was ethereal:
As celestial harps quivered,
This line it delivered:
"For breakfast, try Toasty Oat Cereal!"

limerick_list.author: Bob Dvorak
limerick_list.text:
On the meld, certain face cards earn more
In the pinochle card games for four.
During play, though, is when
All the aces, each ten,
And the kings are the counters: they score.

limerick_list.author: Val
limerick_list.text:
High society families have
A particular word for the lav.
If you're needing the loo,
Saying toilet won't do—
"Lack of breeding," they sneer.  "What a chav!"

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
His writings had caused a sensation
Till the critics condemned innovation.
His early elation
Gave way to frustration,
Then utter demoralization.

limerick_list.author: AndrewB
limerick_list.text:
Our fine army is all-volunteer;
Folks signed up on their own to be here.
But in case of a war,
We may find we need more.
The return of the draft is my fear.

limerick_list.author: PGS
limerick_list.text:
In a botanist's well-ordered files
There's an order with twelve female styles.
In Flora's dominion
That's dodecagynian,
For he-men, a word that beguiles.

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
A fly-cove's suspicious and sly.
Past him nothing and no-one gets by.
He sniffs every whiff,
And it's almost as if
In the back of his head there's an eye.

limerick_list.author: mino
limerick_list.text:
In Glasgow, they know it's their duty
To fight against Satan (Auld Clootie).
They tell that old foe:
"Ye know where ye can go!
On yer way, ye can kiss mah patootie."

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
He's a guy who is tall (that's the best height)
With muscles that bulge under stress—tight
And sinewy, buffed.
So who cares if he's stuffed
In a dress? He's a hunky transvestite.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
I looked up this word, and I found it.
Since its meaning is clear, I'll expound it.
Consider the girth
Of some object on earth—
If it's compassable, you can get round it.

limerick_list.author: Sussexdownsman
limerick_list.text:
If a clear exegesis of text
Is required, then what must come next?
A critical read
Is just what you need.
It's easy, no need to be vexed.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
My advice column, titled "Ask Chuck,"
Has been cancelled for cause, drat the luck!
To folks single or married,
My advice never varied:
"Stop whining!  Be happy, you schmuck!"

limerick_list.author: TrossL
limerick_list.text:
I put clarifier into the water.
Now it sparkles the way that it oughter.
No more swimming pool cloudiness!
(To jumpstart the rowdiness,
Just push in my son or my daughter.)

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Kids, I've brought in some hedgehogs today
To present a hedgehoggy display.
It's conclusively shown
They're collectively known
By one word. What's that noun? It's array.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
On the stage, her translucent camise,
Loose and breezy, seemed certain to please;
But sans camisole under it,
It's surely no wonder it
Was caught in a censorship freeze.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
The cells, say my doctor, are blastic,
Imperfectly formed and dysplastic.
Leukemia looms
(As do hospital rooms).
Let's just say that this news ain't fantastic.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
Muted colors that hint of the earth
Are called earth tones; of them there's no dearth.
For my house, what I'll use
Are those natural hues —
Plus bright reds, whites, and blues, just for mirth.

limerick_list.author: Thomas Taylor
limerick_list.text:
My atlas is now out of date,
For Greenland's been changing of late;
Warming Island's appeared
And this means, as we feared,
There's a rise in the ice-melting rate.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
When your marriage has lost all its fizz,
And your mate says that's just how life is,
If this life you can't face,
Go ahead—play your ace:
Let him know that the baby's not his.

limerick_list.author: BobHale
limerick_list.text:
It seems I'm the poor also-ran.
I've been last since the day's hike began.
I really don't mind
If you leave me behind.
I'll try to catch up when I can.

limerick_list.author: DenmarK
limerick_list.text:
For prescient wagers I'll boast:
As a better, I'm better than most,
But better by far, be
It dogs or the Derby,
I am when I bet ante-post.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
First, it's 45 meters in height.
Next, it's garbage and odious, quite.
It's the famous Mount Cleese.
John gets "honors" like these
When the locals he happens to slight.

limerick_list.author: Frank Luke
limerick_list.text:
The broadcasts and newspapers pull
The same tales from their bag till I'm full.
Stories drone on forever,
Ad nauseam. Never
Repeat them, please—cut all the bull.

limerick_list.author: SusanL
limerick_list.text:
The besuited young men all look smart.
Pin-stripe clad, who can tell them apart?
Wearing ties made of silk,
As do men of their ilk,
Their executive dress is an art.

limerick_list.author: turnip
limerick_list.text:
Antisegregation means rights,
So that blacks attend classes with whites.
Brown v. Board's now effected.
The Supreme Court rejected
Those old Plessy v. Ferguson cites.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
Propositions in math that you prove
By analysis mean you must move
From assuming, as true,
The result right on through
To a statement that's valid. You groove!

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
In our living room, right over there,
Stood a British antique drunkard's chair.
Deep and wide, this chair came
From Queen Anne's time.  A shame
The thing broke from my fat derriere.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
The UK as we've known it is through.
Sound the trumpets or blow the kazoo?
The P.M. and his minions
Shared valid opinions,
But who's driven by Downing Street's view?

limerick_list.author: Sussexdownsman
limerick_list.text:
Alley cropping: this system, we find,
Brings forth crops and trees growing combined
On the same plot of land.
Here the outcome is grand;
For the welfare of both it's designed.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Can I tell you my name? I cannot!
But my code name is "20-Watt Yacht."
I've just come from Pyongyang
Where I photographed—BANG!
(Bob's a bigmouthed ex-spy, newly shot.)

limerick_list.author: VERaLOE
limerick_list.text:
Those who raised me were poor, with no dough
They could spend on a daft VERaLOE,
Who loathed work, hated school
And liked acting the fool—
How I made it? You don't want to know!

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
My pet is a jet-colored boa:
Most affectionate snake that I know-a.
I am naming her Beth.
She could hug me to death,
Though she's currently nibbling my toe-a.

limerick_list.author: Chavi Beck
limerick_list.text:
A useful invention, the broom,
If you happen to live in a room
That conveniently comes
With a floorful of crumbs
And resembles a dust-bunny tomb.

limerick_list.author: Doug Aldridge
limerick_list.text:
The inspector declared it sub-par,
A pub more akin to a scar—
A place for stiff drinks,
But now everyone thinks
That "improvement" means razing the bar.

limerick_list.author: timon
limerick_list.text:
Here we have a concise demonstration
Of unnecessary versification,
Just written to mock
This project: it's floc-
cinaucinihilipilification.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
We were doing cocaine in my den.
"It's the cops!" Now I'm busted again.
Scared and anxious, with coke out,
In a cold sweat I broke out.
I fear a long stretch in the pen.

limerick_list.author: Bob Dvorak
limerick_list.text:
A dirigible, candidly stated,
Is an airship; the word's somewhat dated.
Proponents will swear
Blimps are lighter than air;
Safe to say their balloon's been inflated.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
From the first hated cockcrow of morn,
It's the season of harvesting corn.
Then all evening we husk,
Right from noon and through dusk—
So it's been since my daddy was born.

limerick_list.author: Egbert
limerick_list.text:
My dear fellow, that big cherry-picker's
No good for my rescue. The snickers
Of boys on the ground
Are sure to resound
As I glide down to earth in my knickers.

limerick_list.author: SusanL
limerick_list.text:
Hey there tough guy, you think you're so derf
And the boss over all of this turf?
I got news for ya buddy
You're about to get muddy
And bruised—gonna gimme my Nerf?

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
Extirpative persons like plucking
Up plants by the roots. (Note, I'm ducking
Rhymes censors might say
Must be hidden away;
So of course this poem won't rhyme with … umm…)

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
Global warming! It isn't surprising:
All over, sea levels are rising.
It's eustasy, folks,
Not some ecofreak hoax.
Major land forms are slowly resizing.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
"Your new bra is a strange one, I think.
When your bosoms collide, there's a clink."
"Yes, it sounds like a kettle.
Cups die-cast from metal
Don't shrink. They are made out of zinc."

limerick_list.author: Bob Dvorak
hugh t.
limerick_list.text:
"My first name," said Beth, when I met her,
"Is simply an alphabet letter
(Corresponding to B)
In Hebrew, you see,
So written SIHT EKIL it looks better."

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
I know wood; though I don't like to brag,
I have read every carpentry mag.
As a vigilant reader,
I've learned that the cedar
Of Lebanon shows on its flag.

limerick_list.author: Goldie
limerick_list.text:
You disanimate me with such skill —
Every glance from you gives me a chill.
Both my spirit and body
Are troubled and shoddy;
In your case I know looks could kill.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
As I sought breaths of air (there were none,
Not one puff), Jack returned from his run.
He had B.O. to spare;
I took one breath of heir
And beseeched, "Buy deodorant, son!"

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
My poor daughter's about to be wed
To a der-brain with nought in his head.
Why she chose such a beau,
Though, I'd rather not know.
There are places a dad shouldn't tread.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Said the surgeon, "I can't reconstruct
Your disrupted left deferent duct.
The whole scrotum's destroyed,
And I know you're annoyed,
But that blow to the groin—man, it sucked."

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
If a firm has unfairly dismissed
All the union guys hand over fist,
Then the labor board might
Say the practice ain't right
With an order to cease and desist.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
My Theresa has got beriberi.
I confessed, "This is quite scary, Terry.
It is thiamine, Love,
You don't get enough of,
And the doctors are all very wary."

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
In some restaurants, charges are added.
I hate it if checks have been padded.
When charged in some venues
For use of the menus,
Reacting, I've often "Egad!"-ed.

limerick_list.author: Roger Vick
limerick_list.text:
In Acadia, settlers from France
Were "made British," but most took a stance.
Their nationhood quelled,
They rebelled; were expelled.
Would they take back their land? Not a chance.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Celidography sounds like great fun.
With a telescope, gaze at the sun,
Then describe every spot.
Are you finished? Guess not.
Do the same for the planets. You're done!

limerick_list.author: limarico
limerick_list.text:
We'll dismantle the double-wide, Heather,
Split the halves and protect them from weather—
Looks like you get the bed;
I, the toilet, instead...
Girl, we might as well get back together.

limerick_list.author: Goldie
limerick_list.text:
When you're feeling low down and depressed,
Chocolate ice cream is what I suggest.
It's the magic I use
For expurging the blues
'Cause it brings back my happy face best.

limerick_list.author: mrsrev
limerick_list.text:
Let us go get a stick and a rag
Or a piece of an old plastic bag!
Tie the flag on the stick,
Choose a team—get it, quick—
If you want to play capture the flag!

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Some limericks rhyme moon, June, and spoon
Til I want to escape to Cancún,
Where the women are plenty
And muy caliente,
Each crooning a Mexican tune.

limerick_list.author: art bates
limerick_list.text:
You've decided to take off some weight,
So you skimped on your breakfast at eight;
Then attenuate light,
But at noon lost the fight
When you saw yourself eat and inflate.

limerick_list.author: Len Farano
limerick_list.text:
What were airbrushed from three US stamps
That were issued to honor real champs
Of TV, blues and art?
They were there at the start
But were victims of anti-smoke camps.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
A vowel with marks dieretic
May seem, when in English, synthetic,
But you'd better believe
That a word like naïve
Said "nie-EEV" and not "NAYV" sounds poetic.

limerick_list.author: Jonathan M. Guberman
limerick_list.text:
Well, a model might strike a pro pose,
And The Tell-Tale Heart's a Poe prose,
But I wish I could show
Some puns more apropos
Of the word apropos than just those.

limerick_list.author: zqms
limerick_list.text:
When this main switch (said Albert) is thrown,
My precise calculations have shown
That these gang switches match
The main's signal they catch —
This design I now patently own.

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
Says this wolf in sheep's clothing, "In peace,
I among ewe will walk in this fleece."
Don't believe him: a fake
Who'd deceive. Sneaky snake
Wants to fleece ewe. Baa, humbug! Police!

limerick_list.author: Michael Toalster
limerick_list.text:
Many oxen are kept in a pen,
And students may live in a den.
But wild creatures who slouch
Reside in a couch,
Nipping out for a bite now and then.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
"Apex predators: name what you can."
"OK. Lions, bears, sharks."  "That's right, Dan.
But that isn't a lot —
Plus there's one you forgot:
At the top of some food chains is man."

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
He drank whiskey until he was blotto,
And shamefully chased a tomato.
He defied our belief:
"I'm a big Moro chief!
I'm a visiting Philippine dato."

limerick_list.author: Graham Lester
limerick_list.text:
Saint Amator's tale has a taint:
Does the Church need a bigamous saint?
Since most saints don't have any,
His two were too many,
Yelling, "Oh yes he is!" "No, he ain't!"

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Put an end to all air shows, I say,
Since there's more than just air on display.
Death can come in a trice
When planes crash. That's the price
That both pilots and onlookers pay.

limerick_list.author: Mary
limerick_list.text:
To be brief, here's my major complaint—
My  chief gripe. It relates to the taint
In our chieftain's credentials:
He lacks the essentials,
Since, firstly, elected he ain't!

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
For dinner, there's chicken or veal,
But we'll recognize first a big wheel
In his field and recall
His achievements.  We all
Will appreciate then a good meal.

limerick_list.author: Richard Stehr
limerick_list.text:
Dick Clark on TV—so engaging
That for decades his ratings were raging.
All the while he stayed young.
Now he's numbered among
Those who've gone to where nobody's aging.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Cyclothymic—that's Pete's personality.
Sad or manic, there's seldom neutrality
In his changeable moods—
He enthuses, then broods.
Guess that's Peter's bipolar mentality.

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
Grandma threw Grandpa's shirts all away,
As their cuffs were beginning to fray,
And the collars as well.
Now he's giving her hell —
Poor old girl has the devil to pay!

limerick_list.author: Steve Ngai
limerick_list.text:
—"Once again, I am proving I'm master;
I can't lose, barring utter disaster!"
—"Barring miracles, I'm
Out of luck. With her time,
